newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan puts 96/97 budget gap at 6.2 pct of GDP.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan puts 96/97 budget gap at 6.2 pct of GDP.

text.p: The Pakistan government's economic survey, released on Wednesday, estimated that the budget deficit would reach 6.2 percent of Gross Domestic Product in 1996/97 (July-June), compared to 6.3 percent in 1995/96.
The document, released ahead of Friday's budget for 1997/98, said GDP would grow 3.1 percent this year, against a targeted 6. 3 percent, and compared to last year's 4.6 percent.
It said revenue collection in the first 10 months had reached only 221 billion rupees against a whole-year target of 340 billion, predicting a shortfall of 50 billion rupees.
The survey, which covers the first nine months of the fiscal year, estimated unemployment at 5.37 percent of Pakistan's population, which it put at 135.28 million as of January 1.
It said annual consumer price inflation was likely to rise 11.62 percent in 1996/97, compared to 10.3 percent last year.
